Ada.creator: Jean Ichbiah
Ada.benefits: Strong typing, explicit concurrency, and high reliability.
Ada.description: A statically typed, structured, imperative, and object-oriented high-level language designed for safety-critical and real-time systems. Named after Ada Lovelace, the first programmer.

Red.creator: Nenad Rakocevic
Red.description: A full-stack, next-generation programming language inspired by REBOL. Cross-platform from bare metal to high-level scripting.

Assembly.creator: Kathleen Booth
Assembly.benefits: Direct hardware control, maximum performance, zero overhead.
Assembly.history: 1947. The closest you can get to the metal.
Assembly.description: Low-level symbolic representation of machine code. As close to the metal as you can get, providing direct hardware control with no abstraction overhead.

BASIC.creator: John G. Kemeny, Thomas E. Kurtz
BASIC.benefits: Easy to learn, interactive, historical significance.
BASIC.description: Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code. Designed for ease of use, it brought programming to the masses and powered the microcomputer revolution.

VisualBasic.creator: Microsoft (Alan Cooper)
VisualBasic.benefits: RAD, ease of use, Windows integration, legacy support (Windows only).
VisualBasic.description: A third-generation event-driven programming language from Microsoft. Brought graphical application development to the masses.

Ksh.creator: David Korn
Ksh.description: The KornShell. Combines the best features of the Bourne and C shells with powerful scripting capabilities.

Zsh.creator: Paul Falstad
Zsh.description: The Z shell. A powerful shell with advanced features like better autocompletion, shared history, and theme support.

Tcl.creator: John Ousterhout
Tcl.description: Tool Command Language. An embeddable scripting language with the Tk GUI toolkit.

Awk.creator: Aho, Weinberger, Kernighan
Awk.benefits: Excellent for text processing, one-liners, and data extraction.
Awk.description: A domain-specific language designed for text processing and typically used as a data extraction and reporting tool. Perfect for one-liners and shell pipelines.

Verilog.creator: Phil Moorby
Verilog.benefits: Hardware modeling, simulation, synthesis, industry standard.
Verilog.description: A hardware description language used to model electronic systems. Essential for FPGA and ASIC design.

Smalltalk.creator: Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, Adele Goldberg
Smalltalk.benefits: Pure OOP, live environment, influence on modern GUIs.
Smalltalk.description: The original object-oriented language where everything is an object. Pioneer of graphical user interfaces and modern IDEs.

C.creator: Dennis Ritchie (Test)
C.benefits: High performance, portability, low-level access, massive legacy.
C.description: The foundational systems programming language. Fast, portable, and influential, C shaped modern computing and remains essential for OS kernels, embedded systems, and performance-critical applications.

V.creator: Alexander Medvednikov
V.description: A simple, fast, safe, compiled language for developing maintainable software. Combines the best of Go, Rust, and Swift.

Objective-C.creator: Brad Cox, Tom Love
Objective-C.benefits: Dynamic runtime, C compatibility, Apple legacy.
Objective-C.description: Smalltalk-style messaging on top of C. Powered macOS and iOS development before Swift.

Zig.creator: Andrew Kelley
Zig.benefits: No hidden control flow, manual memory management, comptime.
Zig.description: A systems programming language designed to be robust and optimal, with no hidden control flow or memory allocations.

Dc.creator: Robert Morris, Lorinda Cherry
Dc.history: 1970. The oldest Unix utility still in use.

Vala.creator: Jürg Billeter, Rafał Pietrak
Vala.benefits: GObject system, C performance, modern syntax, GNOME dev.
Vala.description: A programming language using modern high-level abstractions without imposing additional runtime requirements.

XSLT.creator: W3C
XSLT.description: A language for transforming XML documents into other XML documents, HTML, or plain text.

CoffeeScript.creator: Jeremy Ashkenas
CoffeeScript.benefits: Concise syntax, readability, compiles to clean JavaScript.
CoffeeScript.description: A little language that compiles to JavaScript, providing cleaner syntax and introducing features that later became standard in ES6+.

Pascal.creator: Niklaus Wirth
Pascal.description: A structured programming language designed for teaching. Clean, readable, and influential in programming language design.

Sed.creator: Lee E. McMahon
Sed.description: The stream editor. A Unix utility for parsing and transforming text using a simple, compact programming language.

Cobol.creator: CODASYL Committee (Grace Hopper)
Cobol.benefits: Business data processing, stability, massive legacy codebases.
Cobol.description: Common Business-Oriented Language. Powers the world's financial infrastructure, processing trillions of dollars in transactions daily.

SQLite.creator: D. Richard Hipp
SQLite.history: 2000. The world's most used database engine.
SQLite.description: A C library implementing a self-contained, serverless, zero-configuration SQL database engine. The most deployed database in the world.

Crystal.creator: Ary Borenszweig
Crystal.benefits: Ruby-like syntax, C-like performance, static typing.
Crystal.history: 2014. Fast as C, slick as Ruby.
Crystal.description: A compiled language with Ruby-like syntax and C-like performance. Statically typed with type inference for the best of both worlds.

Forth.creator: Charles H. Moore
Forth.description: A stack-based, concatenative language. Minimal, powerful, and extensible—you build the language as you go.

Fortran.creator: John Backus
Fortran.description: The first high-level programming language. Still unmatched for numerical and scientific computing, powers supercomputers worldwide.

CommonLisp.creator: Committee (Guy L. Steele Jr. et al.)
CommonLisp.benefits: Macros, dynamic typing, interactive development, flexibility.

authors.name: Committee (Guy L. Steele Jr. et al.)

CommonLisp.description: An industrial-strength Lisp with powerful macros, dynamic typing, and an interactive development environment. One of the oldest and most capable programming languages.

Pike.creator: Fredrik Hübinette
Pike.benefits: C-like syntax, dynamic typing, automatic memory management.
Pike.description: An interpreted, general-purpose, high-level, cross-platform, dynamic programming language with C-like syntax.

M4.creator: Brian Kernighan, Dennis Ritchie
M4.description: A general-purpose macro processor. The engine behind autoconf and countless text transformation tasks.

Fennel.creator: Phil Hagelberg
Fennel.benefits: Lisp syntax, compiles to Lua, zero overhead, embeddable.
Fennel.description: A Lisp that compiles to Lua. Brings macro power and interactive development to the Lua ecosystem.

Elixir.creator: José Valim
Elixir.benefits: Concurrency, fault tolerance, functional, Ruby-like syntax.
Elixir.history: 2011. Scalable, fault-tolerant apps on Erlang VM.
Elixir.description: A dynamic, functional language running on the Erlang VM. Built for scalability, fault-tolerance, and maintainability in distributed systems.

Rexx.creator: Mike Cowlishaw
Rexx.benefits: Scripting, mainframe automation, ease of use.
Rexx.description: A structured, high-level programming language designed for ease of learning and reading. Popular on mainframes.

Prolog.creator: Alain Colmerauer
Prolog.benefits: Logic programming, AI, pattern matching, declarative.
Prolog.description: A logic programming language where you describe what you want, not how to get it. Used in AI, linguistics, and theorem proving.

Janet.creator: Calvin Rose
Janet.benefits: Embeddable, small footprint, PEG parsing, functional.
Janet.description: A functional and imperative programming language. Lightweight, embeddable, and designed for scripting and system programming.

Wren.creator: Bob Nystrom
Wren.benefits: High performance, small footprint, clean syntax.
Wren.description: A small, fast, class-based concurrent scripting language. Think Smalltalk in a Lua-sized package.

Raku.creator: Larry Wall
Raku.description: Formerly Perl 6, a multi-paradigm language with powerful grammars and Unicode support. Designed as a 100-year language.

Fish.creator: Axel Liljencrantz
Fish.description: The Friendly Interactive SHell. A smart, user-friendly command line shell with powerful features like auto-suggestions and web-based configuration.

PostScript.creator: John Warnock, Charles Geschke
PostScript.benefits: Printing, vector graphics, stack-based, device independence.
PostScript.description: A page description language and programming language used primarily in electronic and desktop publishing.

Gnuplot.creator: Thomas Williams, Colin Kelley
Gnuplot.description: A portable command-line driven graphing utility. The classic tool for scientific data visualization.

Jq.creator: Stephen Dolan
Jq.description: A lightweight command-line JSON processor. Sed for JSON data—slice, filter, map, and transform structured data with ease.

OCaml.creator: Xavier Leroy et al.
OCaml.benefits: Functional, type safety, performance, industrial strength.
OCaml.description: A multi-paradigm language with a strong static type system. Used in finance, static analysis, and theorem proving.

Haxe.creator: Nicolas Cannasse
Haxe.description: A cross-platform toolkit that compiles to multiple targets including JavaScript, C++, Java, and more. Write once, run everywhere.

F_Sharp.creator: Don Syme
F_Sharp.description: A functional-first language for the .NET platform. Combines functional programming with practical OOP for domain modeling and data analysis.

Clojure.creator: Rich Hickey
Clojure.benefits: Immutability, functional programming, JVM interoperability, simplicity.
Clojure.description: A dynamic, functional Lisp dialect for the JVM. Emphasizes immutability, concurrency, and interactive development.

Bash.creator: Brian Fox
Bash.benefits: Ubiquitous, powerful scripting, direct system interaction.
Bash.related: Bourne Shell, C Shell, KornShell, Zsh
Bash.description: The Bourne Again SHell. The default shell for most Linux distributions and macOS. Essential for scripting, automation, and system administration.

C_Sharp.creator: Anders Hejlsberg
C_Sharp.benefits: Strong typing, rich .NET ecosystem, modern features, tooling.
C_Sharp.related: C++, Java, Delphi, Modula-3, F#, Visual Basic .NET
C_Sharp.description: A modern, object-oriented language developed by Microsoft. Combines the power of C++ with the simplicity of Visual Basic for enterprise and game development.

C++.creator: Bjarne Stroustrup
C++.benefits: Performance, object-oriented, rich ecosystem, hardware control.
C++.related: C, Simula, Ada, Rust, D, Java, C#
C++.description: A multi-paradigm language extending C with object-oriented features, templates, and modern abstractions. Powers game engines, browsers, and high-performance systems.

Scheme.creator: Guy L. Steele, Gerald Jay Sussman
Scheme.benefits: Minimalist, clean semantics, first-class procedures, educational.
Scheme.description: A minimalist Lisp dialect with simple semantics. The teaching language of choice for programming fundamentals.

Dart.creator: Lars Bak, Kasper Lund
Dart.description: A client-optimized language for building fast apps on any platform. The language behind Flutter, Google's UI toolkit.

Erlang.creator: Joe Armstrong, Robert Virding, Mike Williams
Erlang.history: 1986. Built for telecom systems that never fail.
Erlang.description: Built for telecom systems, Erlang excels at concurrency, distribution, and fault-tolerance. The foundation for WhatsApp and Discord.

Vimscript.creator: Bram Moolenaar
Vimscript.description: The scripting language of Vim. Customize and extend the legendary text editor.

Octave.creator: John W. Eaton
Octave.description: A free numerical computation language compatible with MATLAB. Essential for scientific computing and algorithm prototyping.

Make.creator: Stuart Feldman
Make.description: A build automation tool that tracks dependencies and builds only what's needed. The foundation of Unix build systems.

Jupyter.creator: Fernando Pérez, Brian Granger
Jupyter.benefits: Interactive computing, notebooks, data science, visualization.
Jupyter.description: An interactive computing environment supporting multiple languages. The standard for data science notebooks and reproducible research.

Perl.creator: Larry Wall
Perl.benefits: Text processing, regex, CPAN ecosystem, system administration.
Perl.history: 1987. The Swiss Army chainsaw of scripting.
Perl.description: The Swiss Army chainsaw of text processing. Powerful regular expressions and one-liners for sysadmin tasks.

Tcsh.creator: Ken Greer
Tcsh.benefits: C-shell compatible, command-line editing, job control.
Tcsh.description: An enhanced C shell with command completion and editing. Popular among Unix power users.

Icon.creator: Ralph Griswold
Icon.description: A high-level language with novel control structures and built-in support for pattern matching and string processing.

Brainfuck.creator: Urban Müller
Brainfuck.description: A minimalist esoteric programming language with only 8 commands. A Turing-complete proof that simplicity can be taken to extremes.

Scala.creator: Martin Odersky
Scala.benefits: Functional + OOP, JVM, type safety, concurrency (Akka).
Scala.related: Java, ML, Haskell, Smalltalk, Erlang, Kotlin
Scala.description: A multi-paradigm language combining object-oriented and functional programming on the JVM. Powers Apache Spark.

Rust.creator: Graydon Hoare
Rust.benefits: Memory safety, concurrency, performance, no GC.
Rust.related: C++, ML, Haskell, Erlang, Swift, C
Rust.description: A systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency. Memory safety without garbage collection.

Groovy.creator: James Strachan
Groovy.benefits: Java compatibility, scripting, dynamic features, DSLs.
Groovy.description: A dynamic language for the JVM with Python-like syntax. Powers Gradle build scripts and Jenkins pipelines.

Julia.creator: Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, Alan Edelman
Julia.benefits: Speed of C, ease of Python, great for scientific computing.
Julia.history: 2012. Looks like Python, runs like C.
Julia.description: A high-level, high-performance language for technical computing. Python's ease with C's speed for data science and scientific computing.

Swift.creator: Chris Lattner et al.
Swift.benefits: Safety, performance, modern syntax, Apple ecosystem.
Swift.description: A powerful and intuitive programming language for Apple platforms. Safe, fast, and expressive.

BASH.history: 1989. The default shell for Linux and macOS.

D.history: 2001. A better C++ that never quite took off.
D.description: A systems programming language modernizing C++ with memory safety, first-class functions, and built-in concurrency. What C++ should have been.

EmacsLisp.description: The extension language of Emacs. Turns a text editor into a programmable environment for virtually any text-based task.

Go.description: Google's answer to systems programming complexity. Simple, efficient, and built for concurrency with goroutines and channels.

Haskell.description: A purely functional programming language with lazy evaluation and strong static typing. The gold standard for functional programming research.

Java.description: A class-based, object-oriented language designed for portability. 'Write once, run anywhere' powers enterprise systems and Android apps.

JavaScript.description: The language of the web. From browser scripts to server-side Node.js, JavaScript is everywhere.

Kotlin.description: A modern, concise language for the JVM and Android. Null safety, extension functions, and coroutines for modern development.

Lua.description: A lightweight, embeddable scripting language. Fast, portable, and the scripting language of choice for games and embedded systems.

Nim.description: A statically typed, compiled systems language. Python's syntax, C's performance, and powerful metaprogramming.

PHP.description: A server-side scripting language powering 80% of the web, including WordPress, Facebook, and Wikipedia.

PowerShell.description: A task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft. Object-oriented shell scripting for Windows and beyond.

Python.description: A versatile, readable language for everything from scripting to machine learning. 'Batteries included' philosophy with a massive ecosystem.

R.description: A language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. The lingua franca of data science and statistics.

Racket.description: A general-purpose, multi-paradigm programming language descended from Scheme. A platform for creating new languages.

Ruby.description: A dynamic, object-oriented language optimized for programmer happiness. The language behind Ruby on Rails.

TypeScript.description: JavaScript with syntax for types. Microsoft's superset adds static typing and modern features to JavaScript.
